channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-387] [Hbase Shell] System.exit() Handling in Jar command
item.description:
I'd like to block the exitVM by System.exit().
Shell should terminate by "quit" command.
item.summary: [Hbase Shell] System.exit() Handling in Jar command

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Fixed it with some refactoring using SecurityManager.

  • added classes { NoExitSecurityManager, ExitException }
  • tableExsits method was used for speed-up in DropCommand
  • some help string modified
submitting.
Re-upload.
re-submitting. (edited some comments)

-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12370394/2297_v02.patch
against trunk revision r598780.

Committed. Thanks for the patch Edward.
Integrated in Hadoop-Nightly #318 (See http://lucene.zones.apache.org:8080/hudson/job/Hadoop-Nightly/318/)

Hey Edward,

I think I figured out how to suppress System.exit and capture stdout/stderr.

Here, System.exit throws a SecurityException, which can be caught above. In this case, I catch in Thread.UncaughtExceptionHandler since I am running misbehaved threads.

I also wrote a class that captures stdout/stderr. Since java only lets me set one printStream to capture stdout per jvm, I have to check Thread.currentThread, and then decide where to write the captured output.

I am hoping to incorporate some of this code into my custom jetty server that submits hadoop jobs.

Oh, Thanks michael!
I'll try to do it.

I tryed.
"System.err.println(switcher.toString());" was clearly worked.

But, .. how can i hide (or catch) a exception message as describe below?


java.lang.SecurityException

        at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.shell.JarCommand$2.checkExit(JarCommand.java:

146)

        at java.lang.Runtime.exit(Runtime.java:88)

        at java.lang.System.exit(System.java:906)

java:39)

sorImpl.java:25)

mDriver.java:68)

sorImpl.java:25)

d.java:189)

hql > _
In other words, UnCaughtExceptionHandler seems not worked.

This is my test code :




  static class InvokeLauncher extends Thread {

    private String[] newArgs;

    private Method main;



    public InvokeLauncher(Method main, String[] newArgs) {

      this.newArgs = newArgs;

      this.main = main;

    }



    public void run() {

      try {

        try {

          main.invoke(null, new Object[] { newArgs });

        } catch (IllegalAccessException e) {

          e.printStackTrace();

        } catch (InvocationTargetException e) {

          e.printStackTrace();

        }

      } catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {

      }

    }



    public Thread.UncaughtExceptionHandler getUncaughtExceptionHandler() {

      return new Thread.UncaughtExceptionHandler() {

        public void uncaughtException(Thread t, Throwable e) {

        }

      };

    }

  }

This is my test code by your example code.
But, exceptions are printed.


java.lang.SecurityException

	at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.shell.ShellSecurityManager.checkExit(ShellSecurityManager.java:47)

      ....

here is a full Log info :
